Explanations about Options.-d(M): A synonym for -depth, for compatibility with FreeBSD, NetBSD, MacOS X and OpenBSD.
Explanations about Options.-empty(M): File is empty and is either a regular file or a directory.
Explanations about Options.-mtime(M):
File's data was last modified n*24 hours ago. See the comments for -atime to
 understand how rounding affects the interpretation of file modification times.
Explanations about Options.-name(M):
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-regex(M):
File name matches regular expression pattern. This is a match on the whole path,
 not a search. For example, to match a file named `./fubar3', you can use the
 regular expression `.*bar.' or `.*b.*3', but not `f.*r3'. The regular expressions
 understood by find are by default Emacs Regular Expressions (except that `.'
 matches newline), but this can be changed with the -regextype option.
Explanations about Options.-regextype(M):
Changes the regular expression syntax understood by -regex and -iregex tests which
 occur later on the command line. To see which regular expression types are known,
 use -regextype help. The Texinfo documentation (see SEE ALSO) explains the meaning
 of and differences between the various types of regular expression.
Explanations about Options.-type(C): You should be able to use "find . -type d -empty".

so_44570230: mask="jpeg jpg png gif bmp pdf"

find . -type f -regextype posix-extended -regex ".*\.("${mask// /|}")"

Explanations about Options.-a(M): Display all of the above information.
Explanations about Options.-c(M): Display the code name of the currently installed distribution.
Explanations about Options.-r(M): Display the release number of the currently installed distribution.
Explanations about Options.-s(M):
Use the short output format for any information displayed. This format omits the
 leading header(s).

Explanations about Options.-P(M):
Interpret PATTERNS as Perl-compatible regular expressions (PCREs). This option is
 experimental when combined with the -z (--null-data) option, and grep -P may warn
 of unimplemented features.
Explanations about Options.-o(M):
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.
Explanations about Options.-r(M):
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.

Explanations about Options.-l(C): I would use "dpkg -l | grep libnuma1" to get the version.
Explanations about Options.-l(M):
List packages matching given pattern.
 -s, --status package-name...
 Report status of specified package.
 -L, --listfiles package-name...
 List files installed to your system from package-name.
 -S, --search filename-search-pattern...
 Search for a filename from installed packages.
 -p, --print-avail package-name...
 Display details about package-name, as found in
 /var/lib/dpkg/available. Users of APT-based frontends
 should use apt-cache show package-name instead.
